message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medial joint line tenderness, limited range of motion, and medial joint laxity suggest a medial collateral ligament injury. Valgus stress test assesses for medial collateral ligament injury, and this test was positive. Medial meniscus injury would show signs of clicking or giving way and tenderness at the joint line. Anterior cruciate ligament injury would present with effusion, a positive Lachman's test, and a positive pivot shift test. Lateral collateral ligament injury would have tenderness over the lateral tibial plateau and positive varus stress testing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tenderness at the medial joint line and medial laxity upon valgus stress suggest a medial collateral ligament injury. Anterior cruciate ligament injury usually presents with a pop sound, rapid swelling, and an effusion, which the patient did not report. Lateral collateral ligament injury usually involves the joint line, which is not the case in this patient. Medial meniscus injury will involve pain, clicking, or locking of the joint during movement, which the patient did not report.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient’s symptoms suggests that the most likely diagnosis is a medial collateral ligament injury. The patient’s hip position and the valgus stress test support this diagnosis. The other options may cause similar symptoms, but do not fit the specific findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medial joint laxity, tenderness over the medial joint line, and the mechanism of injury (tackled from the lateral side) suggest a tear in the medial collateral ligament. Medial meniscus injury would affect the range of motion more and would have tenderness on McMurray test. Anterior cruciate and lateral collateral ligament injuries would have a different mechanism of injury and different physical exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tenderness at the medial joint line and the presence of medial joint laxity suggest a medial collateral ligament injury. Anterior cruciate ligament injury typically presents with pain and swelling immediately after the injury and giving way of the knee during pivoting sports, while lateral collateral ligament injury usually presents with tenderness and laxity on the lateral aspect of the joint. Medial meniscus injury presents with joint line tenderness and pain with rotational movements of the knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tenderness of the medial joint line, limited range of motion, and medial joint laxity suggest a medial collateral ligament injury. Anterior cruciate ligament injury usually has a history of hearing a "pop" sound and immediate swelling, while lateral collateral ligament injury may cause pain at the lateral joint line. Medial meniscus injury may have a positive McMurray test, but this is not mentioned in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of tenderness in the medial joint line and medial joint laxity suggest a Medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury. The other options would have different physical examination findings, such as an effusion with a meniscal injury or a positive Lachman test with an anterior cruciate ligament injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including tenderness along the medial joint line, suggest a medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position, which is indicative of MCL injury. Valgus stress test also confirms this diagnosis, as it elicits medial joint laxity, which is suggestive of MCL injury. Anterior cruciate ligament injury typically presents with the feeling of the knee giving way, while lateral collateral ligament injury typically results from varus stress, which is not present in this case. Medial meniscus injury may cause tenderness along the medial joint line, but it typically presents with locking or catching of the knee joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The key findings in this scenario are tenderness along the medial joint line, limited range of motion, and medial joint laxity on valgus stress. These findings suggest a medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury. The other options are less likely given the absence of specific findings associated with those injuries, such as an anterior drawer test for anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury or tenderness over the lateral collateral ligament (LCL) for LCL injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms include a swollen and tender left knee, limited range of motion, and tenderness in the medial joint line. The valgus stress test indicates medial joint laxity, suggesting a medial collateral ligament injury. Anterior cruciate, lateral collateral, and medial meniscus injuries may also cause knee pain, but their specific symptoms and diagnostic tests are different.
